Daily Classical Music Post

Today is the anniversary of the birth of the English composer Sir Arnold Edward Trevor Bax (8 November 1883–3 October 1953).

http://grooveshark.com/s/Mater+Ora+Filium/4TayjY?src=5

Bax's setting of Mater ora filium (Mother pray thy son), written in 1921, is thought by many to be the finest purely choral work written by an English composer since the Elizabethan era. Bax's setting presents a number of challenges for the unaccompanied double choir, not the least of which is the high C in the Alleluia section that the top trebles have to hold for three bars (which was always my favourite moment when I sang it). The eight-part Amen at the end of the work is absolutely glorious.

It is true that nothing like this had been heard in British choral writing before. Bax reveals his mastery of the use of intense chromaticism at climactic moments, beautifully intertwined with lush harmonies. The Latin verse alternates with English verses based on anonymous 16th-century texts, and each section concludes with an Amen.

Apparently Bax was inspired to write Mater ora filium after hearing William Byrd's wonderful Mass for five voices for the first time. As Edward Dent said: "The result on paper looks an almost unsingable jumble. In performance it was admirably calculated, full of the most adorable surprises."

My classical music post for today is the extraordinary Mater ora filium by Bax.
I used to be able to get up there.
